Recipe yields 2 servings.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cookie and Kate", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/about/"}, "keywords": "Thai fried rice", "image": ["https://cookieandkate.com/images/2014/06/kale-coconut-stir-fry-recipe-3-225x225.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2014/06/kale-coconut-stir-fry-recipe-3-260x195.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2014/06/kale-coconut-stir-fry-recipe-3-320x180.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2014/06/kale-coconut-stir-fry-recipe-3.jpg"], "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/spicy-kale-and-coconut-fried-rice/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 tablespoons coconut oil or quality high-heat oil such as avocado oil, divided", "2 eggs, whisked together with a dash of salt", "2 big cloves garlic, pressed or minced", "&frac34; cup chopped green onions (about 1 bunch)", "Optional: 1 cup chopped vegetables, like bell pepper, carrot or Brussels sprouts", "1 medium bunch kale (preferably Lacinato but curly green is good, too), ribs removed and leaves chopped", "&frac14; teaspoon fine sea salt", "&frac34; cup large, unsweetened coconut flakes* (not shredded coconut)", "2 cups cooked and chilled brown rice**", "2 teaspoons reduced-sodium tamari or soy sauce", "2 teaspoons chili garlic sauce or sriracha", "1 lime, halved", "Handful fresh cilantro, for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat a large (12-inch or wider) wok, cast iron skillet or non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat. Once the pan is hot enough that a drop of water sizzles on contact, add 1 teaspoon oil and swirl the pan to coat the bottom. Pour in the eggs and cook, stirring frequently, until the eggs are scrambled and lightly set. Transfer the eggs to your empty bowl. Wipe out the pan if necessary with a paper towel (be careful, it&#8217;s hot!).", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/spicy-kale-and-coconut-fried-rice/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add 1 tablespoon oil to the pan and add the garlic, green onions and optional additional vegetables. Cook until fragrant or until the vegetables are tender, stirring frequently, for 30 seconds or longer. Add the kale and salt. Continue to cook until the kale is wilted and tender, stirring frequently, about 1 to 2 minutes. Transfer the contents of the pan to your bowl of eggs.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/spicy-kale-and-coconut-fried-rice/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining 2 teaspoons oil to the pan. Pour in the coconut flakes and cook, stirring frequently, until the flakes are lightly golden, about 30 seconds. Cook with me!", "sameAs": ["https://cookieandkate.com/about/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Gluten-Free Apple Tart", "description": "This delicious apple tart features an easy crust made with almond and oat flour. It's gluten free and easily made vegan/dairy free, too (just use coconut oil instead of butter). Recipe yields one 9-inch tart, enough for 6 to 8 slices.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cookie and Kate", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/about/"}, "keywords": "apple tart", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2016/10/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe.jpg", "height": 1513, "width": 1100}, "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (135 grams) firmly packed almond flour", "1 cup (90 grams) oat flour* (certified gluten-free if necessary)", "&frac14; teaspoon salt", "&frac14; cup melted butter or coconut oil", "3 tablespoons maple syrup", "2 large Honeycrisp or 3 medium Granny Smith apples (about 1 &frac14; pounds)", "3 tablespoons maple syrup, divided", "1 tablespoon lemon juice", "&frac14; teaspoon ground cinnamon, plus more for dusting if you&#8217;d like"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To prepare the crust: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit and lightly grease a 9&#8243; tart pan (even if your pan is non-stick). In a medium mixing bowl, combine the almond flour, oat flour and salt, and stir to combine. Drizzle in the butter and maple syrup, and stir until the mixture is moistened throughout.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dump the mixture onto the prepared tart pan. Press the mixture evenly across the base, then use the heel of your palm to press it up the sides as well. Use your fingers to try to make the dough along the sides even in height and depth (see photo). Prick the base of the crust all over with a fork to prevent it from bubbling up. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, until it&#8217;s lightly firm to the touch and just starting to turn golden at the edges. Set aside.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, to prepare the filling: Peel the apples (or don&#8217;t, for more color) and cut them into slices &#8539;&#8243; thick. Transfer the slices to a medium mixing bowl and add just 1 tablespoon of the maple syrup, and the lemon juice and cinnamon. Toss until the mixture is evenly distributed.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange the apple slices across the base however you&#8217;d like, overlapping them as much as possible (I tried to arrange mine like a rose and had a few apple slices left over). Reserve the maple syrup/lemon mixture at the bottom of the bowl for brushing the apples later.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the tart for 25 minutes, then pull it out of the oven and gently brush the remaining maple syrup/lemon mixture over the apples (it&#8217;s fine if you push some of the slices down in the process). Return the tart to the oven and bake for another 15 to 20 minutes, until the apples are very tender and the crust is deeply golden around the edges. While the tart is still hot, gently brush the remaining 2 tablespoons maple syrup over the apples.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/gluten-free-apple-tart-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the tart cool for at least 15 minutes. If you&#8217;d like, sift or sprinkle a little extra cinnamon over the top. If you used a tart pan with a removable bottom, remove the sides. The almonds will go from flour-like clumps, to a ball against the side of the food processor (keep scraping down the sides and breaking up the ball), and finally, it will turn lusciously creamy. If anyone reads this, have faith - it really does come together, into a smooth oily ball. And importantly, the nuts must still be warm, probably to ease the oil's extraction. My first batch was with a bag of ready roasted whole almonds (which weren't warm, obviously) and it took ages. Second load was almonds I had roasted and they worked like a charm. I added the first batch and blended all together. Perfect. Drunk with my success I pulled out a bag of pecans left over from Christmas and roasted and processed those, then added all of the above with a splash of honey. This is honestly the easiest thing to make and is beyond delicious."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lola"}, "datePublished": "2025-01-27", "reviewBody": "I\u2019ve made almond butter a few times, tried your idea of roasting the nuts this time and the flavor is interesting but next time I\u2019ll go back to using raw nuts. This sauce is intentionally bold and spicy and I usually think it&#8217;s just right as written. However, if the flavor is too overwhelming, blend in 1 tablespoon of olive oil while running the food processor. Just add massaged kale, leftover cooked grains and veggies from your crisper drawer. Recipe yields 1 hearty meal-sized salad, so multiply as necessary.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cookie and Kate", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/about/"}, "keywords": "whole grain kale salad", "image": ["https://cookieandkate.com/images/2016/05/anything-goes-kale-salad-recipe-2-225x225.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2016/05/anything-goes-kale-salad-recipe-2-260x195.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2016/05/anything-goes-kale-salad-recipe-2-320x180.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2016/05/anything-goes-kale-salad-recipe-2.jpg"], "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/anything-goes-kale-salad-with-green-tahini-dressing/", "recipeIngredient": ["&frac12; medium bunch kale, preferably the Tuscan/lacinato variety, or several handfuls of your favorite greens", "1 cup leftover cooked grains (I love brown rice, wild rice, quinoa, farro or wheat berries&#8230;)", "2 carrots, sliced into long ribbons with a julienne peeler or regular veggie peeler", "1 radish, thinly sliced and roughly chopped", "2 tablespoons pepitas (green pumpkin seeds) or sunflower seeds, toasted", "More ideas: halved cherry tomatoes, sliced avocado, chopped bell pepper, whatever else strikes your fancy&#8230;", "&#8531; cup olive oil", "&#8531; cup lime juice (about 3 to 4 medium limes)", "Handful of fresh cilantro", "1 small jalape\u00f1o, seeds and membranes removed, roughly chopped", "2 tablespoons tahini", "1 &frac12; teaspoons honey or maple syrup", "&frac12; teaspoon ground cumin", "1 clove garlic, roughly chopped", "&frac14; teaspoon fine-grain sea salt, to taste", "Pinch of red pepper flakes, optional for extra heat"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To prepare the kale (skip this step if you&#8217;re using any other kind of fresh green), first use a sharp chef&#8217;s knife to remove the center ribs from the kale, then discard the ribs. Chop the kale into small, bite-sized pieces. Then, sprinkle the kale lightly with salt, and massage the kale by scrunching handfuls at a time until the kale is darker in color and fragrant. This step reduces the bitterness in the kale and improves its texture.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/anything-goes-kale-salad-with-green-tahini-dressing/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a bowl, combine the prepared kale, leftover grains (I like to warm mine a bit in the microwave first), carrot, radishes, toasted pepitas, and/or your toppings of choice.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/anything-goes-kale-salad-with-green-tahini-dressing/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To make the dressing: Combine all of the ingredients in a blender or food processor and blend until smooth, pausing to scrape down the sides as necessary. Taste, and blend in additional salt if the dressing needs a little more oomph. If you\u2019d like spicier dressing, blend in a pinch of red pepper flakes. If the dressing is too bold for your liking, dilute it with a little more olive oil and blend again.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/anything-goes-kale-salad-with-green-tahini-dressing/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Drizzle the green tahini dressing generously over the salad (you&#8217;ll still have plenty leftover) and enjoy.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/anything-goes-kale-salad-with-green-tahini-dressing/#instruction-step-4"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT15M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 salad"], "recipeCategory": "Salad", "cookingMethod": "By hand", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "34", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "nutrition": {"servingSize": "1 salad", "calories": "484 calories", "sugarContent": "10.9 g", "sodiumContent": "221.3 mg", "fatContent": "20.4 g", "saturatedFatContent": "2.8 g", "transFatContent": "0 g", "carbohydrateContent": "66.2 g", "fiberContent": "12.9 g", "proteinContent": "14.6 g", "cholesterolContent": "0 mg", "@type": "nutritionInformation"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Margaret"}, "datePublished": "2021-09-17", "reviewBody": "I have made this MANY times! Cook with me!", "sameAs": ["https://cookieandkate.com/about/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Southwestern Kale Power Salad with Sweet Potato, Quinoa &amp; Avocado Sauce", "description": "Healthy kale and quinoa power salad with spicy sweet potato, black beans and creamy avocado sauce. If your lime are particularly big, scale back. This gluten-free, vegetarian (easily vegan) salad packs well for lunch, too! Recipe yields 4 generous salads or 6 medium.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cookie and Kate", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/about/"}, "keywords": "power salad, sweet potato kale salad", "image": ["https://cookieandkate.com/images/2024/01/southwestern-kale-power-salad-recipe-225x225.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2024/01/southwestern-kale-power-salad-recipe-260x195.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2024/01/southwestern-kale-power-salad-recipe-320x180.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2024/01/southwestern-kale-power-salad-recipe.jpg"], "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/southwestern-kale-power-salad/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup quinoa", "1 bunch kale, ribs removed and chopped into very small, bite-sized pieces", "2 tablespoons olive oil", "1 medium lime, juiced", "&frac12; teaspoon fine salt", "2 medium sweet potatoes (about 1 &frac12; pounds), sliced into small, &frac14;-inch cubes", "2 tablespoons olive oil", "2 teaspoons ground cumin", "1 teaspoon smoked paprika", "&frac12; teaspoon fine salt", "2 ripe avocados, sliced into long strips", "&frac14; cup lime juice (about 2 limes)", "1 medium jalape\u00f1o, deseeded, membranes removed and roughly chopped", "1 handful cilantro leaves", "&frac12; teaspoon ground coriander, optional", "&frac14; teaspoon fine salt, to taste", "1 can (14 ounces) black beans, rinsed and drained, or 1 &frac12; cups cooked black beans", "&#8531; cup crumbled feta", "&frac14; cup pepitas (green pumpkin seeds)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To cook the quinoa: First, rinse the quinoa in a fine mesh colander under running water for a minute or two. In a medium-sized pot, combine the rinsed quinoa and 2 cups water. Bring the mixture to a gentle boil, then cover the pot, reduce heat to a simmer and cook for 15 minutes. Remove the quinoa from heat and let it rest, still covered, for 5 minutes. Uncover the pot, drain off any excess water and fluff the quinoa with a fork. Set it aside to cool.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/southwestern-kale-power-salad/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To cook the sweet potatoes: In a large skillet, warm the olive oil over medium heat. Add the chopped sweet potatoes and toss to coat, then add the cumin, smoked paprika and salt. Stir to combine. Once the pan is sizzling, add a scant &frac14; cup water, then cover the pan and reduce heat to low to avoid burning the contents. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the sweet potato is easily pierced through with a fork, about 7 to 10 minutes.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/southwestern-kale-power-salad/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Uncover the pan, raise the heat back to medium and cook until the excess moisture has evaporated and the sweet potatoes are caramelizing on the edges, about 3 to 7 minutes (add another little splash of olive oil if the potatoes start sticking to the pan). Set aside to cool.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/southwestern-kale-power-salad/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To prepare the kale: Transfer the kale to a large mixing bowl. Sprinkle the chopped kale with salt and use your hands to &#8220;massage&#8221; it, which improves the flavor. Just grab handfuls of kale in your hands and scrunch it up in your palms. Repeat until the kale is darker green in color and more fragrant. Whisk together 2 tablespoons olive oil, the juice of 1 lime and &frac12; teaspoon salt. Drizzle over the kale and toss to coat.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/southwestern-kale-power-salad/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To make the avocado sauce: Combine the ingredients as listed in a food processor or blender. This lively succotash recipe features corn and lima beans (fresh or frozen), peppers, basil and butter. It's best enjoyed soon after cooking. Recipe yields 6 side servings.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cookie and Kate", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/about/"}, "keywords": "succotash", "image": ["https://cookieandkate.com/images/2020/09/succotash-in-cast-iron-pan-225x225.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2020/09/succotash-in-cast-iron-pan-260x195.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2020/09/succotash-in-cast-iron-pan-320x180.jpg", "https://cookieandkate.com/images/2020/09/succotash-in-cast-iron-pan.jpg"], "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/succotash-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil", "4 ears fresh corn, shucked (or about 3 cups frozen corn, thawed)", "1 teaspoon fine salt, divided", "1 small red onion, chopped", "1 poblano pepper, chopped", "1 red bell pepper, chopped", "Optional: 1 medium jalape\u00f1o, ribs and seeds removed and chopped", "2 cloves garlic, pressed or minced", "2 cups fresh or frozen lima beans*, thawed under cool running water", "2 tablespoons butter, plus more for serving", "Freshly ground black pepper, to taste", "Optional: Pinch of cayenne (for even more spice)", "\u00bc cup chopped fresh basil, divided", "2 tablespoons chopped green onion", "Flaky sea salt or kosher salt, for serving\u00a0"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large skillet over medium-high heat, warm the olive oil until it&#8217;s starting to shimmer. Add the corn and &frac12; teaspoon of the salt. Cook, stirring every minute or so, until the corn is turning golden on the edges, about 5 to 7 minutes (be careful, sometimes it hops out of the pan when it&#8217;s hot).", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/succotash-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the heat down to medium-low. Add the onion, poblano, bell pepper, jalape\u00f1o (if using) and the remaining &frac12; teaspoon salt. Stir to combine, scraping up any browned bits on the bottom of the pan as best you can. Cook, stirring often, until the onion is tender and turning translucent, about 5 to 8 minutes.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/succotash-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the garlic to the pan, stir to combine, and cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add the lima beans and cook until they&#8217;re warmed through, about 2 minutes.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/succotash-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter to the skillet and stir until it&#8217;s mostly melted. Remove the skillet from the heat. Let it cool for a few minutes. Taste, and season with freshly ground black pepper. Add a tiny pinch of cayenne pepper if you&#8217;d like it to have more of a spicy kick. Stir in about half of the basil, reserving the rest for garnish.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/succotash-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the succotash to a serving plate, if desired. Top with the remaining basil and all of the green onion. Add a few more pats of butter and sprinkle it lightly with some flaky salt or kosher salt. Serve soon. This dish is best enjoyed within a couple of hours after making, but it will keep well in the refrigerator, covered, for up to 4 days.", "url": "https://cookieandkate.com/succotash-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT35M", "recipeYield": ["6", "6 side servings"], "recipeCategory": "Side Dish", "cookingMethod": "Stovetop", "recipeCuisine": "American", "suitableForDiet": "VegetarianDiet", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "22", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "nutrition": {"servingSize": null, "calories": "265 calories", "sugarContent": "9.3 g", "sodiumContent": "415.3 mg", "fatContent": "12.1 g", "saturatedFatContent": "4.6 g", "transFatContent": "0 g", "carbohydrateContent": "36 g", "fiberContent": "6.3 g", "proteinContent": "7.8 g", "cholesterolContent": "15.3 mg", "@type": "nutritionInformation"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "\u201dVegetarian", "description": "\u201dWatch", "contentUrl": "https://content.jwplatform.com/videos/&rdquo;nqNt3kJF&rdquo;.mp4", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://content.jwplatform.com/thumbs/&rdquo;nqNt3kJF&rdquo;-720.jpg"], "uploadDate": "1970-01-01T00:00:00+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mario Inganni"}, "datePublished": "2020-09-24", "reviewBody": "I have made a recipe nearly identical to this and it's really great! My brother and I were excited by the Native American connection. Pretty sure it was canned or frozen corn and lima beans boiled in a saucepan, drained, probably with butter, salt and pepper. \r\n\r\nI started eating it more often when I became a vegetarian in my mid-teens, inspired by the amino acid combining breakthrough book: Diet for a Small Planet - great book for theory, but get your recipes from Kate. My version was just steamed corn and lima with some olive oil, salt and pepper.\r\n\r\nThis recipe is MUCH MORE DELICIOUS. Having made it once, my only issue is the limas - I used frozen. I thawed them as directed and tasted one. It seemed clear that just the two minute heat up would leave them too tough and starchy. I steamed them for 10 minutes and they were still a little starchy. I'll try 15 minutes next time.\r\n\r\nWhile researching Cooking Lima Beans, every source said they must be cooked for 10-15 minutes to break down the cyanide they contain. Aside from potential toxity, has anyone prepared the lima beans as described in the recipe and been happy with them?\r\n\r\nI'm a vegetarian, my girlfriend has Celiac. It was vegetarian, but given the butter added at the end in both family versions, not vegan. This recipe is perfect as written and I love the colorful veggies. For the person who couldn't find poblanos, they are pretty widely available in my small town now--Walmart always has them--but years ago, I subbed Anaheims or canned green chilis in recipes that called for poblanos. I've also used edemame in succotash, and even kidney or pinto beans--I think pretty much any bean goes!
